title: John's Low Back Conundrum
clinical_history: John is a 45-year-old software engineer who spends the majority of his day working at a computer. Over the past 3 months, he has experienced intermittent low back pain that has become progressively more disruptive. He first noticed the pain after an intense week of meeting project deadlines, during which he spent prolonged hours seated at his desk. The pain is described as a dull ache, located in the lower lumbar region, which sometimes radiates into the right buttock (P2). The pain is worse in the morning and tends to ease off slightly by midday but becomes frustratingly persistent by late afternoon.
aggrevating_factors: sitting for extended periods, lifting heavy objects, prolonged standing, sudden movements like twisting and bending
picture: [insert image of person highlighting the lower back region]
easing_factors: temporary relief from gentle walking, lying down on a firm mattress with knees bent, use of heating pads
past_history: No significant past medical or surgical history related to the spine. Occasionally experiences mild neck pain due to long work hours.
medical_history: History of hypertension for which he is taking medication regularly. Non-smoker and moderate alcohol consumer.
medications: Lisinopril for hypertension, Ibuprofen as needed for pain management
personal_history: Lives with his wife and two children. Enjoys cycling on the weekends but has been unable to do so recently due to the pain. Sedentary lifestyle due to the nature of his work.
imaging: None ordered at this time. Preliminary assessment suggests muscular tension rather than structural spinal issues.
